caseNameFull: In the Matter of the Application of Grace Foote Schultz for a Writ of Habeas Corpus on Behalf of Baby Boy Schultz.

opinions.snippet:
I feel impelled to dissent from the majority opinion in this case.
The pertinent facts involved in this proceeding may be summarized as follows:
Grace Foote Schultz, the petitioner on behalf of Baby Boy Schultz, is the unmarried mother of said baby boy, who was born out of wedlock on October 21, 1946, at the St. Mary's hospital, in Reno, Nevada. The evidence upon the hearing reveals that the petitioner came to Reno in July 1946, and called upon a physician some time in August 19

posture:

(HORSEY, J., dissenting.)

opinions.snippet:
An action was brought by the mother, Tillie Knutsen, the administratrix of the estate of Thelma Knutsen, *Page 476 
deceased, for the recovery of damages against Edgar Dilger for the wrongful death of her daughter, Thelma Knutsen. At the close of the testimony, the defendant moved for a directed verdict. The jury returned a verdict for the plaintiff, and defendant moved for judgment notwithstanding the verdict. Both motions were overruled, as was the motio

posture:
Appeal from Circuit Court, Yankton County; HON. A.B. BECK, Judge.

Action by Tillie Knutsen, as administratrix of the estate of Thelma Knutsen, deceased, against Edgar Dilger. From an adverse judgment and order, defendant appeals. Judgment and order affirmed.

caseName: De Kalb County v. Tennessee Electric Power Co.
caseNameFull: De Kalb County v. Tennessee Electric Power Co.

opinions.snippet: This action was brought by De Kalb county against the Tennessee Electric Power Company to recover damages for the destruction of a bridge across Caney Fork river at Holmes creek, which bridge was owned by the county. The bridge was washed away on the night of Saturday, March 23, 1929, by an unprecedented flood in Caney Fork river. The county claimed that this was the proximate result of negligence and improper manipulation of the dam owned and maintained by the Tennessee Electric Power Compan

posture: Appeal from Circuit Court, De Kalb County; R.W. Smartt, Judge.

attorney:
R. B. Evins, of Birmingham, E. S. Jack, of Greensboro, and Pettus  Fuller, of Selma, for appellants.

Evidence of the cost of an article is always admissible when its value is a subject for determination. Hill Groc. Co. v. Caldwell,  211 Ala. 34 ,  99 So. 354 ; Colorado Mid. R. Co. v. Snider,  38 Colo. 351 ,  88 P. 453 ; Hollinger v. M. K.  T., 94 Kan. 316 ,  146 P. 1034 , Ann. Cas. 1916D, 802; Behm v. Damm (Sup.) 91 N.Y.S. 735; Globe v. Rabogliatti,  24 Ariz. 392 , 210 P. 685 ; Union Co. v. Los Angeles,  184 Cal. 535 ,  195 P. 55 ; Oliff v. Howard,  33 Ga. App. 778 ,  127 S.E. 821 . On the question of removal of the cause, counsel cite Burlington, C. R.  N. Co. v. Dunn,  122 U.S. 517 ,  7 S.Ct. 1262 ,  30 L.Ed. 1159 .

Harsh  Harsh, of Birmingham, and Hobbs, Craig  Brown, of Selma, for appellee.

A cause not removable when brought, by reason of diversity of citizenship, cannot be made so by any act of the defendant or defendants or the court, and can only become so by a subsequent pleading or proof of facts disclosing removability existing when suit was brought. K. C. Suburban Belt R. Co. v. Herman, 187 U.S. 63 ,  23 S.Ct. 24 ,  47 L.Ed. 76 ; A. G. S. v. Thompson, 200 U.S. 206 ,  26 S.Ct. 161 ,  50 L.Ed. 441 , 4 Ann. Cas. 1147; Lathrop, Shea  Henwood Co. v. Interior Const. Co., 215 U.S. 246 ,  30 S.Ct. 76 ,  54 L.Ed. 177 ; American Car  F. Co. v. Kettelhake,  236 U.S. 311 ,  35 S.Ct. 355 ,  59 L.Ed. 594 ; Anaconda Copper M. Co. v. Butte-Balaklava Copper Co. (D.C.) 200 F. 808; Texarkana Tel. Co. v. Bridges,  75 Ark. 116 ,  86 S.W. 841 , 5 Ann. Cas. 246; Bailey v. Southern R. Co.,  215 Ala. 677 ,  112 So. 203 . The burden was upon defendant to show proper construction, equipment, repair, and operation of its engine. A. G. S. v. Davenport,  195 Ala. 369 ,  70 So. 674 .
caseNameFull: SOUTHERN RY. CO. Et Al. v. BAILEY

opinions.snippet: At a former trial of this case on the petition of the Southern Railway Company, a foreign corporation, an order was entered for its removal to the United States District Court on the ground that the circuit court sustained a demurrer to the evidence by the only resident defendant. On appeal to this court, referring to well-established principles, it was shown that the situation thus disclosed did not furnish sufficient justification for the removal, and the judgment was reversed.
